case_vignette:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increased urinary frequency over the past month. She also reports having dry mouth and feeling thirsty all the time despite drinking several liters of water per day. She has not had any weight changes and her appetite is normal. She has a history of obsessive compulsive disorder treated with citalopram. She drinks 1–2 cans of beer per day. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Na+ 130 mEq/L
Glucose 110 mg/dL
Osmolality 265 mOsmol/kg
Urine
Osmolality 230 mOsmol/kg
The patient is asked to stop drinking water for 3 hours. Following water restriction, urine osmolality is measured every hour, whereas serum osmolality is measured every 2 hours. Repeated laboratory measurements show a serum osmolality of 280 mOsmol/kg and a urine osmolality of 650 mOsmol/kg.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Renal and Genitourinary System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been going to the bathroom a lot more than usual over the past month, feeling really thirsty all the time, and my mouth is pretty dry even though I've been drinking lots of water every day.
How old are you?
I am 30 years old.
Do you have a family history of diabetes?
I haven't mentioned any family history of diabetes.
Do you have a medical history of diabetes or any other chronic conditions?
I have a history of obsessive compulsive disorder, but I didn't mention having diabetes or any other chronic conditions.
Are you currently taking any medications for any condition?
Yes, I'm taking citalopram for my obsessive compulsive disorder.
**Final Diagnosis:** Type 1 Diabetes
